keyTakeAways: Richard Kenneth Djerf was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 killings of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix.
Djerf was convicted of sexually assaulting Rochelle Luna, murdering Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, and Damien Luna, and was motivated by revenge over a prior theft involving a family member.
The execution marked Arizona’s second death row execution of 2025 and the 39th execution of the year, highlighting ongoing use of capital punishment despite past controversies.
The process took about 10 minutes, with delays due to suboptimal vein conditions, and raised concerns about compliance with expert standards for lethal injection procedures.
Arizona has faced criticism for past botched executions and lengthy IV insertion times, leading to pauses in executions since 2014, including a review in 2023 and a subsequent reversal in 2024.
The state's death row now includes 107 prisoners, and five more executions are scheduled nationwide this year, underscoring national debates over the death penalty's fairness and effectiveness.
Attorney General Kris Mayes supported the execution, stating that the victims' loved ones deserve closure, reflecting a political and moral justification for capital punishment.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Richard Kenneth Djerf, a 55-year-old man convicted of killing four members of the Luna family—Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, Rochelle Luna, and Damien Luna—in Phoenix in 1993, was executed by lethal injection in Arizona on October 18, 2025. Prosecutors allege that Djerf, driven by revenge for a prior theft, attacked the family, sexually assaulted Rochelle, and murdered the others through beatings, stabbing, and shootings. The execution was the second in Arizona during 2025 and the 39th of the year, following years of pauses due to concerns about botched procedures and public criticism. The process took approximately 10 minutes, with delays due to difficult vein access, and raised questions about compliance with expert standards. Arizona has faced criticism for past execution issues, including a botched 2014 execution of Joseph Wood, leading to a pause in 2014 and 2023. Governor Katie Hobbs had previously paused executions in 2023, but after a 2024 review and policy changes, executions resumed. With this execution, Arizona’s death row now holds 107 inmates, and five more executions are scheduled across the U.S. this year, indicating continued national debate over the death penalty.
title: Arizona Executes Man for 1993 Killing of Four Luna Family Members
